title: Latest News from Science Magazine
description: Keyword search result for Alerts: News Weekly Headlines -- New results matching your keyword search query (updated daily).

items.title: These stinkbugs coat their eggs in fungi to protect them from parasitic wasps
items.description: An unusual relationship could shed light on how insects choose their partners

items.title: On an Arctic archipelago, frozen soil may preserve a hidden history of viruses
items.description: Scientists are hunting for ancient RNA in Svalbard’s permafrost, hoping to shed light on the evolution of viral diseases

items.title: As his fraud trial looms, Alzheimer’s scientist is exonerated by his university—sort of
items.description: Excusing record-keeping “misconduct” flagged in earlier investigative report, City University of New York concluded in letter that image doctoring by Hoau-Yan Wang was not proved

items.title: Ancient sea turtle discovered in Lebanon reveals a surprising evolutionary history
items.description: Oldest known sea turtle soft tissues could help reveal how a variety of vertebrates adapted to ocean living

items.title: Famed Japanese primatologist settles lawsuits over mishandled contracts
items.description: Tetsuro Matsuzawa agreed to pay Kyoto University $219,000 to end legal dispute

items.title: Polluted weapons factory begins locking up nuclear waste in glass
items.description: After years of delay and political wrangling, DOE’s Hanford site opens vitrification plant

items.title: Poisonous sacs helped toads conquer the world
items.description: Iconic amphibians took an unexpected path across the globe, study finds—with toxins as a “game changer”

items.title: Did lead poisoning doom Neanderthals?
items.description: Modern humans’ tolerance for the toxic metal may have helped them outcompete our closest evolutionary cousins

items.title: An ancient cousin to humans probably built tools with its huge hands
items.description: New fossils reveal Paranthropus had massive yet dexterous hands

items.title: Chicago’s beloved ‘rat hole’ was actually made by a squirrel
